abstractContent.text: When people use natural language in natural settings, they often use it ungrammatical-ly, leaving out or repeating words, breaking off and restarting, speaking in fragments, etc.
Their human listeners are usually able to cope with these deviations with little difficulty.
If a computer system is to accept natural language input from its users on a routine basis, it should be similarly robust.
In this paper, we outline a set of parsing flexibilities that such a system should provide.

We goon to describe FlexP, a bottom-up pattern matching parser that we have designed and implemented to provide many of these flexibilities for restricted natural language input to a limited-domain computer system.
